content.description: This climb is two routes to the right of "Shoot Up or Shut Up".  The beginning is probably the hardest part where you will need to start on some small balancy crimpers.  The name Zig Zag is true to this climb as you start from the right of the wall and zig up to the left then zag back to the right and so on.
content.protection: 4 draws or so and perhaps a #2 cam right under the roof.

content.description: A bolted friction route on a narrow column of rock.
content.protection: 5 bolts and a 2-bolt station
content.location: Between "Chocolate Chunk" and "Practical Religion".

content.description: Right of High Desert Drifter. Good moderate,though still soft Navajo rock, will clean up to be a nice moderate.
content.protection: tips- 3 camalot

content.description: Tradiak! Crux climbing getting to, and past, the first bolt brings you to a stance and traverse that it would be best not to fall off of. After the second bolt, easier but still thought-provoking climbing leads up and left to the anchor. This route has great face climbing that is classic for the style.
content.protection: 5 bolts - Crashpad helpful
content.location: Arching black slab just left of Half Pipe

content.description: this route starts to the left 60' left of El Cracko Diablo.  Start in a left facing corner, natural gear is needed. continue up bolted face passing 5 bolts to two bolt anchor.
content.protection: quickdraws, hand size cams.
content.location: 60' left of Coup d'Etat

content.description:
No lines at the base of this route.  As the name implies, this is an offwidth.  It is located right of

Potstash

, an obvious 5.9 sport pitch on a roadcut, and left of

Big Sky Mud Flaps

.  There are a wide variety of interesting moves required on this route, but the crux boils down to good old fashion off width grunting.

At any rate, adequate protection can be had with a #5 camalot (or 2) and a rack of standard gear.  If you have something bigger, bring it as the #5 camalot will tip out and fall out at the most desperate places.

I'd recommend left side in on the bottom section.  I stymied myself at the crux by going right side in, and now I'm of the opinion it would be better to go left side in on the upper section.  Fortunately there's a drilled angle at the crux if you get discombobulated.
content.protection: Standard rack, plus whatever wide gear you can find.

content.description: First moves are protected by two drilled angles.  Crux lies after this and before the roof/bulge.  A number 2 cam fits under the roof.  Roof moves are good even though it looks sandy.
content.protection: BD c3s to number 2 cam, quick draws.
content.location: Behind the willows in between Visable Panty Line and Frogs of a Feather.

content.description:
This is kind of a sporty route, as far as climbing with gear goes.  Little bit everything on this one from a hand jam, to finger slots, to not-so-obvious stemming to friction. It doesn't look like much from the ground, but it climbs fairly well.

If you're a snobby climber - don't bother with this one.  We'd all hate to hear another whiny climber.  However, if you're the type of climber that likes to climb for the sake of experience, versatility, and simple fun, then put on those shoes and put this baby up.

If you're up for it, on the way down Visible Panty Line, set up a top-rope on High Over Datura to the right.  Although the TR of this face might not be worth it to you unless you are willing to try 5.11+ friction and balance.  It's a humbling and a learning experience.
content.protection: Mostly TCUs and stoppers.  Actually, I probably only slotted one nut.  One friend for down lower, don't remember which size, but you can tell from the ground what you'll need.  One quickdraw for a piton at the crux.

content.description: This route is quintessential Wall Street; great movement on ok/pretty good rock. Tenuous climbing leads through the first 20ft to the first bolt, then great moves lead upwards toward the crux. The last few bolts escalate into powerful lay-backing, gastoning, and stemming, utilizing the classic vertical runnel features often found here.
content.protection: Crash pad and a yellow or green Alien to get to the first bolt, then draws for the remainder
content.location: Immediately right of Jacob's Ladder

content.description: Less than vertical face climbing for the first 3 bolts at the bottom. Then a crack with one or two hand jams to a ledge. Then an easy climb/scramble on a short slab to the anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts at the bottom. Then two or three cams. BD .5-2
content.location: Just to the left of Ring Pin

content.description:
Also called

The Bush Line

, pitch one climbs the right trending crack.  Second pitch is lower angle face climbing.
content.protection: 00-3 camalot, And a few runners.  the baby angle on pitch one mentioned in Eric's book, is no longer there.  Pitch two has three drilled angles.  Anchors could not be seen.
content.location: Just left of seibernetics.

content.description: Under the Boardwalk begins with a somewhat awkward sequence on the right arete to a high first bolt. Move out onto the face clipping a couple of old 1/2" bolts, trending left to the twin-arete feature. The climb changes shape here becoming thuggy compression climbing up the prow.  The angle eases off two bolts before the chains but the climbing stays tenuous until they're clipped.
content.protection: 8 quickdraws.
content.location: Located a couple of routes left of Nervous in Suburbia. Look for the obvious prow and the typical bail biner four bolts below the chains.

content.description:
An extension to Smell of Dead Euro-peons. Josh said he was cool with "Uncertain" as the name. It kind of describes the climbing on the pitch.

Bolts lead up and left from that anchor. Classic WS awkward pulls and smears on sandy rock in the opposite direction as you would like.
content.protection: Small cam to get started, then bolts
content.location: Just right of Bolts to Bumpyland

content.description:
A continuation of Pinhead, start on that route but about 8 feet below its anchor, bust right and up to an obvious OW pod guarding access to the right-facing corner above.  This is the first of three OW sections you will encounter on your way to the anchor.  You will want a #5 Camalot and bump it up this section with you.

Grunt up to the next section of wideness, #4 works here.  As the crack disappears you will find a nice new bolt waiting for you to clip.  Stem, smear and grovel up to the last short pod below the anchor.  Have a #2 Camalot ready, plug it in and make a move or two to the anchor.

When I led this I used everything from a 00 C3 (purple) to the #5 Camalot (purple) hence the route name.  It is still fresh, so be mindful of what you grab onto.
content.protection: Cams from tiny to #5 Camalot, save a #2 for the top.  1 bolt on the route and a three bolt anchor with chain and rapid links.  Please do not pirate the links.

content.description: Located 2 routes to the right of 30 Seconds Over Potash.  I believe this is a rarely done route, but it is truly fun and challenging. I would give it 3 stars, but the drilled pins near and at the top of the climb was placed in some awkward spots. Use a #3 or #3.5 in the roof hand/fist crack near the top.  Solid 11b route requiring a combination of skills including smears, fine footwork, crimps and jams.  The crux is a small bulge about 2/3 of the way up.  The key here is definitely footwork.
content.protection: Combination trad sport, but mostly sport.  5 draws, 2 #3 cams and 1-2 small aliens or equivelent.

content.description:
Mixed line.

4 bolts of tricky vert climbing between two short crack sections, then 10 feet of easy slab.

Protection::: #2, 4 bolts, #3, #4, bolt, anchors.
content.protection: #2,3,4 and 5 bolts + anchors.
content.location:
From “30 Seconds Over Potash”, walk to the right past “Rhino Might” and “Right Side In”.

If you reach “Sand and Steel” you’ve gone too far.

content.description:
If there are 40 routes on Wall Street then this definitely ranks in the Top 40.  I wouldn't plan a road trip around it, but this is worth doing if you're looking for one of the few 5.8 leads in the desert or a warm up.

This left facing corner is distinguished by two drilled angles at the top.Upward progress can be made via almost any climbing technique: laybacking, jamming, stemming, etc.  Locate the route on the left side of the cliff before encountering the second top roping area.  To its left lies Lacto Mangulation (5.10b) a right facing corner with several bolts and to its right is skeletron (sp?) a bolted 5.11d.

Descent: Short rap to ground ~ 50 feet.

It looks possible to climb passed the anchor on Top 40 via a thin hand crack and achieve the top of the anchor on skeletron.
content.protection: Standard rack (nuts fit in a couple spots) + 2 quickdraws for the drill angles.

climbs.name: Tired of Talus
climbs.fa: Bret Ruckman, Gary Olsen 1988.  Pitch 2 & 3 Jim Beyer, Pat McInerney 1991

content.description:
This is a quality yet overlooked route on Wall Street.  It throws a lot of variety at you from finger tips to wide and keeps you thinking the whole time.  It is steep and fairly sustained.  The first 30 feet are slightly overhanging and good rest are few.  Most people only do the first pitch.  If you have climbed Astro Lad, Potash Sanction and Static Cling, this is the next step.

P1. Charge off the ground into the 10 inch to 4 inch crack to a stance(photo at right).  Then, climb fingers and tips,  a short hand crack and into a sort of shallow chimney.  Then, on up to the large ledge with anchors visible from road. Don't park your car or your dog at the base when climbing this one.  Some loose rock may be encountered especially towards the top.  This route would be a classic if the rock was solid the whole way.  The rock is mostly solid, a bit sandy in spots and soft at the top although easier.  Quite worthy regardless.    One 70 meter rope to rappel or two 60's.

P2. Climb up and left on 5th class to the base of right facing corner with a beautiful thin splitter crack.

P3. Climb the beautiful thin crack (5.12 according to Bjornstad) to older looking anchors. Several tips to finger size pieces may be necessary.

Other P2.  From the top of the first pitch climb slightly down and traverse right past some  newer bolts and then straight up following bolts to an anchor 5.?.

Other P3.  Climb the left facing corner above. 5.?

Note:  I have only climbed pitch one.  I provided the other pitches in hopes that someone with better beta could fill in.  They look really good but hard [to me].  I hope to climb them someday.  I certainly will update the description if I do.
content.protection:
Standard desert rack plus one or two large pieces for the start.  A 5 camalot works well.  Plus a few extra tips to finger size pieces including a purple C3 or black Alien.

One 70 meter rope to rappel or two 60's.
content.location: The next route right of Static Cling (20 feet).  60 feet left of Eat the Rich.

content.description:
Interesting movement utilizing edges, laybacks, hand jams, and rattly fingerlocks.  Bring a red c4 and a yellow tcu - the placements will be obvious (and necessary).

This route is listed as "unknown" 5.12b in the Moab area guide.  Definitely worth doing! Will clean up with some traffic, there was 0 chalk and a fair amount of sand when I got on it.
content.protection: 4 Bolts, #1 C4, yellow TCU, bolted anchors.
content.location: Left of Pinhead and right of Potash is a mini-corner in jet black rock. Mostly bolted with bolted anchors.

content.description: The crux is protected by a fixed piton above the white sploch.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 1 piton, 2-bolt station with chains.
content.location: The left edge of a trapezoidal friction slab.

content.description: sandy slab moves past the first bolt lead to a bush and hidden gear placement before following incredible jugs and more slab to the top.
content.protection: Four bolts with .5/.75 between bolt 1 and 2. Use anchor up and left from school room slab.
content.location: Right of the first school room slabs. A tree used to live at the base but was removed hastily by UDOT in early summer 2107. The tree may grow back?

content.description:
"Oh you can take your time baby, I'm in no hurry....."

Balance-y and harder-than-it-seems climbing leads through the first two bolts to a delicate clip at the 3rd. Powerful moves getting established over the roof bring you to a jug for a rest. Easier climbing leads to the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts
content.location: Aréte just right of Mother Trucker

content.description: This thing is supposed to clock in at 5.9.  We made it up the first two pitches; the first pitch is a shallow off width with minimal small gear at the back. The second pitch is awesome. You deal with a corner with a two large cracks coming at you one from each side. Worth doing for the second pitch. After that you have to be comfortable with chimneys or bring lots of Gold Big Bros because its really wide and really long. There is a detached pillar at the top of the 2nd pitch on which we put some webbing around and a rap ring to bail off. There is not fixed gear on the route except for what is described as a single pin to rappel off of at the top". Lots of loose rock and besides my party I havent seen anyone on it before. Be prepared for a famous Beyer Adventure.
content.protection:
1st pitch:Small stuff (nuts and small cams)

2nd pitch: Large (5 Camalot) to hand size cams pieces

3rd pitch:large Big bros

4th pitch:unknown
content.location:
to the left of Jingus Launch

Mystery Route and just to the right (3 feet-ish) of Wild-eyed Dear.

content.description:
I thought the patina on the rock looked like a stegosaur oriented vertically hence the name.  Fun movement throughout this short route.  Thoughtful and  balancy climbing for the grade.

Crux comes early moving past bolt one on the tail section of the stego.  Still engaging moving through a short corner near the top.
content.protection: 5 bolts, 3 bolt chain anchor
content.location: Starts about 30 feet to the right of the school slabs.  It sits between two TR routes, an eroded bulge problem on the left and a "crack" line on the right.

content.description:
A classic slab marked by thin cruxes and tip-toe foot work. This climb will require balance and a little confidence. Fairly well protected, this tenuous route has only one definite crux, but plenty of "heads-up climbing" everywhere else. A wandering line with good movement and mass appeal.  A great lead and a really nice climb!

While the grade has been debated, 5.10a/b (E1 5b for our visitors) seems to be the benchmark. Your size, reach, and skill will become a prime factor when coming to your own consensus; expect fluctuations.
content.protection: Six to eight draws lead to a two-bolt anchor.
content.location:
Located further down the road towards the petroglyphs,

Steel Your Face

can be found immediately off the road and 30 feet left of a

School Room

style slab area. It is directly left of a vegeteted section of the wall which is home to

Puppy Love

.

content.description:
Climb the thin crack system and pull up under the roof utilizing some side pulls (crux).  Pull the roof (2nd crux) and continue to anchors on the right wall.

The moves are aesthetic, and you can find some great rests, a great route.

Although it certainly won't compare to longer classic routes, it is definitely one of the best on wall street.
content.protection: A set of camalots to a number 3, small pieces (tcu's) are helpful, and a set of nuts.  Draws to extend pieces below the roof.
content.location:
This route is located about 50 feet right of Top Forty in a highly chalked left facing dihedral with a thin crack system, and a roof about 2/3 of the way up.

There is a chalked up flake to the left that leads to the same anchors, Potash Bong Hit, a top rope climb.

content.description: This is one of the best crack pitches at Wall Street. The crux comes early, with small gear and powerful moves. After the first twenty feet the difficulty eases into really enjoyable fingers and tips climbing.
content.protection: Tiny gear and/or stoppers for the crux. The rest goes well with triples of fingers and tips pieces of BD, Metolious, and Alien sizes up to .5BD.
content.location: In the gully to the left of Under the Boardwalk and just right of I Love Loosey. Obvious crack line with bouldery tips start.

content.description: Climb up the center of the slab past five fixed anchors to a bolted belay.  It looks thin but the low angle makes it possible.
content.protection: 5 quickdraws
content.location: Located about 60 feet left of Baby Blue just left of a deep sandy recess.  It starts behind some bushes up a large fin like protrusion. The route climbs up the slab in the middle of the fin.

climbs.name: Smoke Filled Rooms
climbs.fa: Billy Smallen, Grug, Herb Crimp, July 2008

content.description: This is a fun and super varied route! Start off either straight below the crack on big rails (5.10a-ish) or over left in the depression of the ledge (5.10d-ish) and then walk into the crack. Get a couple pieces (#1 Camalot in the corner, #0.75 Camalot a move above in the first pod). Pull on the corner finger crack and get a stemming rest on the ledge. Transfer into the main crack and climb up clipping the bolt right before the crux sequence. Face climb above the bolt either pulling into the bottoming crack (harder) or stemming and face climbing straight up. Get a hand hold higher than the anchors to make the clip, poor rock above limited my anchor placement options.
content.protection: 1 each 0.3 Camalot to 2 Camalot, 1 bolt. It is possible to place a Red/Yellow Hybrid Alien (or maybe just a red alien) and a large micro stopper in the last pod before the bolt. It is also possible (but probably to hard to be worth it) to place a large stopper a couple moves above the bolt.
content.location: This route is right (upriver) about 150ft from the far right side of Schoolroom #1 one climb right of Midnight Frightening'. The straight up start begins behind a bush on a large slopping gold colored ledge below a very varnished wall, a bolt is visible about 8ft down and left of the anchors.

content.description:
This well bolted slab route is located just to the right of the bush below

Puppy Love

.  Pull a 5.7 move off the deck and clip the first of many closely spaced bolts.  A good intro to soft sandstone fiction climbing.  Rap from a two bolt anchor at 90ft to prevent deep rope groves from top ropping.

This route used to have only 2 bolts on it.
content.protection: 7-8 bolts
content.location:
This well bolted slab roue is located to the right of Puppy Love and Steel your Face.

GPS: 38.5457282,-109.5996269

content.description:
The crux is at the top two bolts, bit spooky and run-out to the chains. An excellent route all the same, even more so in the afternoon, when it is in the shade.

However, this route is much more exciting if you don't have a guidebook and start up it because it "looks cool"....

I think this is the best "sport" route on Potash Road.
content.protection: Four bolts, but you'll need gear to 1 Camalot, emphasis small stuff.  Fixed anchors at top with rings; 50 meter rope fine.
content.location: In RIGHT facing corner to left of Static Cling, starts directly under tree.  Rappel.

climbs.name: Shoot Up or Shut Up Corner

content.description:
Climbs up the corner with tenuous stemming and crimping followed by a couple of bulges and work right to finish at the shared anchor with Shoot Up or Shut Up and Frogs of a Feather.

Karly Kelley's

High on Moab

describes this as an old toprope that was recently equipped as a lead. Good climb on great rock in the corner with some softer rock in the bulges.
content.protection: Four bolts plus small gear for the start.
content.location: Just left of Frogs of a Feather and Shoot Up or Shut Up is this corner climb. Sneak behind the bushes to get to the start.

climbs.name: Shoot Up or Shut Up
climbs.fa: Kyle Copeland, Charlie Fowler, Marc Hirt and Tim Hudgel '89

content.description:
This route begins just to the climber's left of reflector post #4 and is on the next major buttress to the right of the Summit Chimneys area.

Climb up and then move left following bolts and placing gear.
content.protection: A set of cams up to #2 Camalot, 6 quickdraws, a few runners.

content.description: A short, boulder-problem start leads to a long slab with thin edges and friction moves. There is a low crux off the ground and another crux about halfway up. And let's be honest, it's probably not good to top rope this route or the Slab Route to the left. The sandstone is soft and you can see many rope grooves here already. Rapping, instead of lowering, would cause the least impact on the rock.
content.protection: bolts
content.location: Right of Slab Route (5.7) about 40 feet at a small alcove with an angled calcite strip in otherwise maroon colored rock.

content.description: This is a fine route that can be found between a bushy crack and sandy floored chimney about 50 yards to the right of the Indian drawings on Wallstreet.  It doesn't seem to get much traffic, possibly due to the runout to the first pin.  If you climb even near the grade the first bit to this pin shouldn't be a problem.  The crux is found between the third and fourth pin where a small bulge must be passed with very thin feet and minimal hands.
content.protection: Five drilled pitons to a 2 drilled piton belay.

content.description: Climb up and left onto a small ledge past two drilled angles and into a right-leaning dihedral.  The dihedral is more of a groove than a crack and difficult to protect without taking away all holds; the slab to the right is 10- and offers little but nubbins for feet to help.  Climb up to even with the anchors and then traverse a flake-top to the excellent anchors (placed for both this climb and the slab TR of Seibernetics Direct, 10-).  Rap or lower 80'.
content.protection: Standard rack with a handful of QDs (two SS bolts and a good double-bolt anchor).  Bring small to medium passive pro as well as active.

content.description: Climb the low angle water runnel in a left facing corner to a bolted anchor with chains.
content.protection: Single set from Purple Metolius to Blue Camelot with extra finger sized pieces. Bring a nut tool to excavate placements. 70m rope to rap.
content.location: Walk up into the pruned trees and find the start just right of a bolted line.

content.description: This is an obvious seam to the left of Seibernetics and Unemployment Line. The climbing is tenuous, with tiny protection. Very cool route.
content.protection: Tiny. Triples or even quadruples of grey sizes (BD worked best) through purple TCU size. A few pieces in the finger and tips range, as well as a .75 or two and a hand sized piece for getting to the bolt.
content.location: Obvious seam to the left of Seibernetics. Starts as a shallow left facing corner.

content.description:
School Room Slabs offers four TR climbs on Potash Road with an easy 4th class scramble to the anchors.  Most of the routes are in the 5.4-5.5 range, although a couple of variations at the start of some of these climbs can provide a little more of a challenge while still on TR.

If you have a small trad rack, you can also lead a short crack to the left of the tree where the 4th class scramble to the top is located.  This is a super fun 5.5/5.6 lead (60ft) with bolted anchors and you can easily TR this after you lead it.  This was our group's favorite route.

This area is highly recommended for kids, newbies and large groups of gym climbers who happen to be in the area for the weekend and want to get in a few hours climbing.  We managed to get a group of 8 on three routes each in under 3 hours.
content.protection:
Two-bolt anchors at the top of each route.

The left-most variation is now bolted for sport.

Light rack of nuts or cams to lead the short 5.5ish crack to the left of the tree. Green alien to a #2 or #3 camalot.
content.location:
Drive down Potash Road from town and pass the Jaycee campground. School Room slabs are near the start of Wall Street, at the second pullout on the right after the campground. The main section of Wall Street starts immediately after these slabs. The anchors are reached by a 4th class scramble directly above the lone tree near the middle of the slabs to a ledge at the top of the climbs. I'd wear climbing shoes for this scramble if you're not used to desert rock.

38.551179, -109.596264

content.description: Climb the right-facing dihedral.
content.protection: 2 fixed pitons and a 2-bolt station.
content.location: The dihedral immediately left of the top of "Full Spectrum".

climbs.name: Room With A View (free)
climbs.fa: Equipped by Luke Malatesta, 2006. FFA: Jason Lantz

content.description: The free variation of the aid route of the same name. Interesting climbing zig-zagging back and forth across the seam past four bolts. The seam opens up in small sections to accept supplemental gear. The grade I gave the route is just my best guess, there's a tricky crux move after the second bolt but otherwise the climbing is fairly reasonable after. Expect a veneer of fine silt in sections until perhaps it cleans up with more traffic.
content.protection: Quickdraws for four bolts, stoppers, small to hand sized cams.
content.location: The first route to climber's left of Knapping With the Alien. Look for two bolts punctuated by a large gap between two more bolts higher up.

content.description: short s splitter in the cove left of Flakes of Wrath 500ft.Bouldery start!
content.protection: tips- 1 camalot

content.description: Poor rock quality. Don’t lead this.
content.protection: Bolts to a 2-bolt station with chains.

content.description:
This is the crack about 15 feet right of "30 seconds over Potash." Start with some hands and short wide pods that take you to an offwidth, which as the name implies, is best climbed "right side in." Near the top some smaller gear can be placed in a seam.  At the thin seam, face climb up and left to rock over the vertical section.

This is actually not that bad of a route and would be better if there were an anchor.  Currently, you could use the anchor by "30 seconds," but that would probably be in the way of the masses. So, it is possible to traverse to the (climber's) right to the obscure "bolted route," about 30 feet right of "30 seconds) and lower down.  At this point, the "Bolted Route" (5.11a) can be TR'd.

This route, with some large cams, would be a good route for those working on their offwidth skills.
content.protection: Some finger sized pieces, hands, and cams up to 6".

content.description:
A good newish sport climb that goes up the arete right of 30 seconds.  Crux is about 2/3 up.

Off the ground to a V2ish boulder problem to a no hands rest.  Move right onto crimps, then left toward the arete (crux).  Fairly sustained from shortly before the crux to the finish jug.  Some friable holds the higher you go.  Alternatively, you can ride the arete from the no hands to above the 5th bolt.

As with other new sport routes, some redpoint cleaning may continue so get on it before it's gone.
content.protection: 7 or 8 bolts
content.location: Arete climbers right of 30 seconds

content.description:
A steep route with limited options and a committing finish. Climb an inclining slab passing bolts to a soft arete and corner.

Delicate moves from beginning to end, this line is short, but full of surprises. A good climb that is fairly well protected; finish at a chain anchor.
content.protection: Draws and a few long runners for about six bolts.
content.location:
Earlier on Potash Road, this climb is directly left of

Fistful of Potash

and just right of

Mini Me

.

content.description: Another neglected route, with a distinctly difficult start in some of the best varnish at WS, and a somewhat wild ending over the roof. Good and varied climbing, with only a little choss.
content.protection: Doubles of fingers, tips and less than, with a single set other than that. 1 bolt protects the roof moves near the end.
content.location: Starts in a highly varnished, left-facing tips corner just right of Junk in The Trunk. Anchors visible high up on the left wall.

content.description:
Starts right of

Steel Your Face

in the trees.  This climb felt harder than

Steel Your Face (10a)

, and was certainly more difficult to protect.  Basically bad gear placements up a thin sandy seam, and of course, sandy slab climbing.  Make sure to follow the easiest climbing about 2/3 of the way up (I got tunnel vision and tried to go straight to the next pin).  Also, be careful of the crumbly flake near the top.

Gosh my review makes this climb sound fun, doesn't it?
content.protection: Bring some cams to #2 camalot - small Splitter Cam would have been nice on this one - to supplement several drilled pitons.

content.description: Climb the low angle slab covered in sand.  Unpleasant movement leads to even lower angle climbing.
content.protection: 4 bolts.  3 bolts anchor.
content.location: Look for a broken gully on the left and another slab route next to the wide crack on the right.

climbs.name: Pounding The Frog Redirect
climbs.fa: Nate Sydnor, Ed Oak, Gaar Lausman and Jordan Hill

content.description:
This route is a logical ending to Pounding The Frog Direct. We came up with all sorts of funny stories about why that route ended up veering directly right into Visible Panty Line, and I would love to know if anyone has the actual info. The new terrain takes you up one of the last prominent unclimbed features at Wall Street.

You start off on PTFD, busting the boulder problem then voyaging straight up after the three pitons. Fun and engaging climbing past three well-spaced bolts brings you all the way up the prow and into Best Route Ever where you'll finish on the final corner of that route. Some of the holds may need to be approached lightly but anyone who knowingly voyages up this thing should understand how to proceed accordingly.
content.protection: I used a crash pad for the beginning because the moves getting to the first piton are likely the hardest of the whole route. There are 3 original drilled angles, 3 new protection bolts, then one final bolt of BRE and some fingers/tips/tiny gear for the end. The route will likely take every bit of a 60m rope so tie a knot in the end.
content.location: On the prow just left of Visible Panty Line. Start on PTFD and go straight up

content.description: This route is pretty good. 3 drilled-angle pitons lead up the blunt prow just left of Visible Panty Line and just right of Pounding The Frog. After the three pitons angle up and hard right into VPL. The climbing before the traverse and link-up with VPL is the best, with a cool boulder problem getting off the ground. Definitely the potential for a long swinging fall if you blow it before reaching VPL.
content.protection: 3 drilled angles then a couple of cams for VPL - don't fall on the traverse - a crash pad helps getting to the first piton
content.location: Left of Visible Panty Line and right of Pounding The Frog

content.description: Face climb past 2 bolts to anchor consisting of one rap ring and one chain. Best Route Ever crosses the anchor.
content.protection: 2 draws
content.location: Located in small pull out right of what is now called Points West, or pre bolts, Smell of Dead Euro-peons.

content.description:
Also referred to as

Little Thailand

. A Fun, not-that-well-protected intermediate lead. Crux is the move after you've clipped the last bolt before the anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor
content.location: 100 feet to the right of the Indian Writings sign on Potash Road, just to the left of a sandy-floored chimney (route on the right side of the chimney is Shadowfax).

content.description: This route climbs a left-facing corner system and is located 30 feet left of Pinhead and to the right of an old aid line marked by pin scars. Use a variety of techniques up to and over the offwidth roof and continue to the anchors. There is a drilled angle on the left wall before the roof.
content.protection: A set of cams up to #3 Camalot with some extras in the hand and smaller sizes as well as a #5 Camalot (old style) for the roof. You will be able to see what gear is needed for most of the route from the base.

content.description:
Start 15 left of Static Cling.  Do a few moves to get into the splitter hand crack formed by the main wall and a giant flake that leans into the corner to the right that forms Static Cling.  Climb the splitter then follow the crack up the most obvious line which  trends right and widens about 30 feet up until you reach the Static Cling anchors.  A bit harder for small hands or people with little jamming experience.

This climb is described in some guide books as a top rope.  It protects well the entire climb but the fact that you are climbing a giant detached flake becomes more obvious the higher you climb.  The flake must weight many tons and is reasonbly solid but I suggest placing cams on the upper section in such a way that the outward force of a cam would exert a force on the flake pushing left/right of you as you face the rock (toward Static Cling) versus into/away from the rock (toward the road). It may be possible to push the flake outward but definitely not to the right toward Static Cling.  This may not be possible in the wide section but is possible on the upper part of the route.

Thump the flake up high with the heal of your hand and discover where the name of the climb came from.  Sorry, the name doesn't refer to taking a bong hit.
content.protection: Camolots: single set from .5 to 4.  Extra 1's and 2's for the hand crack.
content.location: This route is right of Skeletonic and just left of Static Cling and shares the same anchors as Static Cling.

content.description:
Trad start to bolted finish, varied climbing on good stone.  Layback up a right trending flake, clip a bolt and pull through a bulge using a big arrowhead shaped incut.

Pass two more bolts, stepping up on a pedestal and clip the anchor.  An  extension heads left past a few more bolts.  This bumps the grade to 11+/12-.
content.protection: .5 Camalot will protect you to the first bolt. Bolts from there to the first anchor, 10b.
content.location: 20 feet left of Lizard Skills and just right of Bolts to Bumpy Land

content.description:
Great lead for the 5.10 climber... but one that will challenge you to stay on top of good gear placements through the bottom.  It is located to the right of Astro Lad and is the next route immediately right of Potash Sanction.

Make your way upwards using an array of cracks and features.  Soon you'll probably want to angle left towards the right-facing dihedral.  Trickier moves set you up for a very short chimney session and then the reach out and around from the chimney to clip the anchors.

It is not recommended to bypass the chimney, although people do it frequently.  Can anybody comment on the pitches up higher above this anchor?

As always on Wall Street use your own hardware while your crew topropes this.
content.protection: All gear, no bolts or pitons.  You can probably bring a single set.

content.description:
This route was not unpleasant, it just was not worth much. I did it because I was there, I was waiting, and I was antsy. It's a better boulder than it is a route. It is also easier than the book would imply, & reasonably solid and secure.  IF it were 90' long, there would be a line for it.

There is not and apparently never was a hidden anchor up top as indicated by the book. Again, just solo this up or down in combination with Manicured Lawns (5.9) or Dunn-Copeland (5.7).

All of these routes lie on the arch-shaped flake which lies against the main wall between Nervous In Suburbia and Lucy In the Sky with Potash. Pedigree Poodles ascends the right hand side of the flake to the top, perhaps for 20+ feet. The moves are not hard and the rock is pretty good. It will take good small cams if you like. You can place cams back behind the flake up top, but the cables will get tweaked hard if someone takes a fall on them or hangs. I lead this route on a few pieces of gear in a solid arc over to the top of Dunn Copland and then down the sloping ramp of that route. I reached the ground, and handed the lead line to my second, who back lead it in reverse- pulling the gear out by reversing my direction. This turns the 2 routes into a mellow rising and falling traverse of the system covering ~50-60 feet of climbing.

To reiterate, this climb was far easier than the given grade of 5.9+, and has no anchor, nor has it apparently ever had one. It is a safe boulder though- it's just too short to be a good route.
content.protection: Cams .5-1".  Just a few, plus cams to 2-3" for the top.

content.description: Climb first half of Potash Sanction 5.10d then traverse left and climb the left facing corner then right facing corner.
content.protection:
Mixed .5-3 BD Camalot

2 long runners

9 quickdraws

content.description: I couldn't quite bring myself to give a 50 foot sport route on Wall Street 3 stars, but this is a really really good route all the same.  Devious face climbing reminiscent of Eldo (thin edges that slant the wrong way, etc.).  It starts 2 climbs left of the prominent and popular LF corner, "30 Seconds Over Potash" (in between is a thin .10a LF corner, Lucy in the Sky with Potash").  The first bolt is a bit high (climb in from the right), but once clipped it will be at your waist for the crux sequence.  Above is 5.8-5.9ish climbing with 3 adequately spaced bolts, to a good bolted anchor.
content.protection: 4 bolts.  I didn't notice any gear placements.  A 50-M rope works fine.

content.description: Very good trad route.  Begins with small finger crack and face moves.  The crack expands to good hand size midway up.  Crux is at the top with strong face moves and lay-back
content.protection:
Small cams up to .75 or 1.  Good C3 Placements, and really solid mid-size nut placements at the top.

The Anchors are hard to reach from the top and many may find the best approach is to just lunge for them.

content.description: Mississippi High Step is a tough face route that stays less than vertical the entire way. Most climbers will find the technical cruxes to come right off the ground and then again about half way up the route.
content.protection: Five fixed pieces (bolts and drilled angles) to a two bolt anchor with chains.
content.location: Mississippi High Step is 30 feet left of Flakes of Wrath.

content.description: Start up Mini Me passing 2 bolts, skirt the upper half of Minii Me by stepping left on good stone past 3 more bolts to the anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts, chain anchor
content.location: Start on Mini Me

content.description: A slab that surmounts the right edge of a small bulge.
content.protection: 8 bolts and a 2-bolt station with chains.
content.location: Between "Brownie" and "Chocolate Chunk".

content.description:
Also called the

Fistful Corner

is done entirely on gear, This route is right of "Last Tango In Potash" and can be lead on all gear via crack out right or via a two bolt variation off the ground. The 2 bolt face variation out left.
content.protection: 2 draws, 3/4- 3 camalot

content.description: Start below a giant flake to the right of Schoolroom #1. The crux is right off the ground so you may want a crash pad. Start in thin crimps that don't let up until you hit the flake--awesome moves! Once you reach the flake traverse right and place a #2 camalot or a #3 friend in the pod--then continue right. After placing another #2 Camalot (just as the flake jogs upward) do a huge undercling pullup and move right, clip a bolt (a kneebar may help for clipping) then traverse right to another undercling where you can get handjams (and a #1 Camalot). You may then want to place a 0.5 Camalot where the crack constricts. Traverse farther right where you can get a 0.3 camalot in a pod at your knee, then climb up, clipping a bolt, to the anchors!
content.protection: 3 Bolts, 2 #2 Camalots, 1 #0.3 Camalot, 1 #0.5 Camalot, 1 #1 Camalot
content.location: This route is the first route right of Schoolroom #1,and 2 climbs left of Smoke Filled Rooms on a giant flake that trends upriver from 15-40 feet off the ground.

climbs.name: Mephistopheles
climbs.fa: Scott Deputy, Amanda Smith 2007. FFA Mason Earle

content.description: 40 feet of fun liebacking ends with 3 bolts of horrendous, insecure stemming. More 5.11 leads to the anchors. There are more pitches above that haven't been done in many many moons.
content.location: the big corner that starts off the ledge above skeletonic

content.description: Moderate mixed climbing leads to thin crux on the upper portion of the arete.
content.protection:
.75, 3#, 4#, camalot

6 bolts
content.location: Left of "Baby Blue".

climbs.name: Lucy in the Sky with Potash

content.description: Fun roadside route between 30 seconds over potash and nervous in suburbia.  Starts off as hands, moves to fingers, with a cool couple face moves, then back to fingers.  Watch out for a couple loose flakes toward the top (someone drew a big chalk "NO" on one of them).  They seem pretty solid; just don't pull out on them to hard.
content.protection: Mix of stoppers, small cams, and a couple hand sized cams.

content.description:
Excellent slab climbing up rippled stone.  Pinches, laybacks, fingerlocks; this short route packs a lot of techniques in 55 feet of engaging climbing.

The line starts just left of a left angling seam and finishes in a left facing corner.
content.protection: Bolts to chain anchor
content.location: Located well left of Visible Panty Line and 20 feet right of Points West.

content.description:
Mixed route, pretty sandy now, a mix of potash choss and good stone.  Start below the shallow corner, green camalot in a slot about 8 feet up, then clip three bolts that lead to a short wide slot with a chockstone.  Move past this and up right to a 2 bolt anchor with chain.

The tufa's are on the left side of the corner.  Actually they look more like those alien worms from the beginning of the X Files movie.
content.protection: Green camalot, #4 camalot, #3 camalot and a tips piece.  3 bolts complete the pro.  Anchor is 2 bolts with chain.
content.location: In the shallow corner between Lacto Mangulation and Banana Peel.  The start is directly behind the tree.

content.description: The crus is about half way up the corner.
content.protection: A few cams and a 2-bolt station shared with "Hidden Message".
content.location: The dihedral on the right edge of a distinct slab. Between "Hidden Message" and "Brownie".

content.description: Same bolted station as Arc Angel.
content.protection: Bolts to a 3-bolt station.

content.description: Great Route with lots of thin balancy and technical moves. All the old pins have been replaced with bomber bolts. Dont cheat yourself and stick your fingers in the old pin holes!
content.protection: six qds, a #2 and some small nuts and cams if you dont want a bit of a runout.
content.location: to the right of Pinhead \ and left of Fist full of Potash.

content.description: Lacto Mangulation is the first route left of Top Forty and the last route before School Room #2. It starts on a small face for about 20 feet (5.6) to a ledge and then follows a right facing dihedral that starts as a fist crack and ends up as a small finger crack. The last 8 feet is the crux. Rap from slung anchors. Can be top roped from School Room #2.
content.protection: There are two drilled angles and one bolt leading to sling anchors, a couple of larger cams(#4) could be used to protect a longer fall between the second and third bolts but not necessary.

content.description: Fun crimps and mantles up an ever-so-slightly under vertical wall.  Hard for short people.  All the hard moves are at bolts, and/or from large ledges that you can safely land on if you miss.  Good holds all the way.
content.protection: 5 drilled pins and chains
content.location: OBVIOUS sport route on edges, about 50 yards right of Bad Moki Roof.

content.description: Just another Pretty Face is a great thin, balancey face climb at the far end of Potash Road.  It is located immediately left of a thin seam called "Chris-Cross," and can be identified by a first bolt 25 feet off the deck.  The line arcs gently to the left and then finally heads up and then back right to the anchors.  Tiny edges and sandy nubbins for the feet, and lots of off balance long reaches make for great fun on this pitch.  The book lists the crux as between bolts 3 and 4, but I found the climbing to be pretty cruxy from bolt 3 right to bolt 6.
content.protection: Six bolts/pitons to a two bolt anchor.  Runout to first bolt - you can protect this by climbing up the neighboring crack, placing a friend, traversing and clipping the first bolt, then back-cleaning the friend, but why bother?  If you are not comfortable soloing the 5.8 terrain to the first bolt, you probably will struggle on this climb.

content.description: Easy climbing leads to the #2 placement, then you'll find some odd cracky climbing to, and past, the first bolt. The #3 goes in, and one more awkward move gets you to the next bolt. Very cool moves constitute the crux; getting established and transitioning left. The remaining rock in the upper part isn't the most stellar, but the climbing is engaging, and the fact that the pitch is so long is cool.
content.protection: 9 bolts, with a #2 & 3 Camalot. 60m rope with a knot in the end
content.location: Just right of Faith Flake

content.description: Fun small roof move Then route angles left.  And shares anchors for the two climbs to the left
content.protection: two drilled angles. Nuts- #4 cam
content.location: Left of gully from Visable Panty Line.  Small opening in bushes leads to base of climb.

content.description:
Wow. It's kind of a shame that Beyer didn't bolt this one to be more approachable. Likely one of the better face climbs I've done at Wall Street.

The route features amazing varnish, and SUSTAINED climbing. A ground-up lead of this thing would likely be one of the more amazing accomplishments at the crag, and it amazes me that Beyer would have led it the way it is. I would LOVE to hear of someone leading this thing.

Mid 5.12 climbing leads one through multiple hard moves over 35 ft. to the first bolt. After that, stacks of .10d to .12a moves lead upwards. Amazing climbing with a long section of double-gastoning these crazy runnel features.
content.protection: Not much
content.location: To the left of Jug Roof. The face is beautiful, and you will see the first bolt way up there.

content.description:
A zesty route with old school appeal. Short and intense,

Jacob's Ladder

is a

psychological thriller

packed with lots of climbing. If this climb had a tag it would read:

"Handle With Care"

. Don't let this route become your "ladder"...

Square up in the center of the face and find the most featured area to begin, run it out about twelve or thirteen feet over a thin and thoughtful slab. Gain a decent rest and clip the first bolt, take time here to ponder; continue on, execute the crux, stay heavy on those feet. Pass a few more bolts and keep your wits for the final moves to the anchor.
content.protection: Draws for four bolts and an anchor. A stick-clip can be used, this eliminates some of the risk but also detracts from the route's character.
content.location:
Jacob's Ladder

is the short slab just right of

Shadowfax

. It lies at the south end of

Wall Street

and is about 75 feet north (right) of the Petroglyphs and two routes right of

Potstash

.

content.description: This Route is Rated 11c in the Desert Rock Guide Book.  Way Harder than that though.
content.protection: 6 Bolts to Anchor
content.location: From Nervous in Suburbia go Three Bolted Routes Left, Past the Gully and it is the First Route at the corner on the other side of the Gully

climbs.name: Horizontal Mambo
climbs.fa: Luke Malatesta et al, FFA: Mason Earle, November 2010

content.description: Climb the low angle dihedral start of Bad Moki Roof but head right under the big roof along positive holds in the horizontal crack, clipping the fixed draws, rather then up the leftward thin hand crack of BMR. Most of the holds are good but feet are non-existent so some horizontal positioning is required to prevent campusing the route. Really fun. Crux comes right at the end.
content.protection: A few small pieces in the .3 to .75 camalot range for Bad Moki start, one draw for first bolt, then fixed draws to finish.
content.location: Same start as Bad Moki Roof. Look for the fixed draws heading horizontally below a big roof.

content.description: Typical Wall Street low angle slab.  A bit sandy, but fun for new leaders or climbers. Gradually becomes lower angle as the route progresses.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chains.
content.location: First bolted route left of Gramma and...

content.description: This is about as good as the rock gets at Wallstreet, with very cool sculpted holds and engaging, thought-provoking movement throughout. Care should be taken by both belayer and climber getting to the 2nd pin, as a fall will put you very close to the ground.
content.protection: 3 drilled angles and 2 bolts
content.location: Immediately right of Visible Panty Line

content.description: The crux is above the last bolt.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 1 piton and a 2-bolt station with chains.
content.location: Straight up the middle of the face between "Tastes Like Chicken" and "Lip Balm Addict".

content.description:
Left facing corner has poor quality rock slightly left of corner for the first 20 feet.

-Start up left facing corner

-Route becomes thin just before the first bolt (1st crux).

-Making last move to the anchors is quite exciting, 2nd crux between pin and anchors.

Great route that is beginning to see more traffic
content.protection:
#1 Metolius thru #2 BD

2 QD's needed for bolt and pin

Anchor:

3 bolt anchor right of corner
content.location: Immediately right of Welcome to Anexia, 5 bolt sport route. 100+ foot right of Bad Moki Roof

content.description: Shallow gully just left of Snake Slab. Steepens to a short, fun chimney.
content.protection: Small to medium gear. 2 bolt anchor with chains.
content.location: Just left of Snake Slab, in a shallow gully.

climbs.name: Grama and the Green Suede Shoes

content.description: Climb the obvious wide crack to the left of Lacto Mangulation. It's lower angle but wide which can make it akward. There are two anchor options if bringing up a second, either traverse to the chain anchors (climbers right) or run it out another fifty feet to a boulder that can be slung (couldn't find anything else).
content.protection: Doubles of #3-5, no need for anything small.
content.location: Part of the school room area, left of Lacto Mangulation. Find the low angle wide crack. Across the street from a "Parking" sign. Walk off to the climbers left avoiding kicking down rocks on the unsuspecting passerby. It's

climbs.name: The Good, The Bad, and the Potash

content.description:
We put this up yesterday. Climb the perfect handcrack that is

Potash Bonghit

, then traverse left on good edges (for Potash) that don't all aim the way you'd like. It was gonna be much longer, but something important broke... so its stopped as is.
content.protection: Four #3 friends and 3 quickdraws.
content.location: This route climbs the handcrack and face between Static Cling and Skeletonic.

content.description: This route starts to the right of "Shoot up or Shut up".  Follow the flake up to the crack.  At the top of the crack (look for a bolt) move left and climb up to the chains
content.protection: Cams and 1 draw for a bolt at the top

content.description: 5.9+ hand jams lead up to thinning double cracks. When the crack runs out, keep climbing the face with no bolts.
content.protection: Cams. No bolts. Anchors at top.
content.location: This crack shares anchors with Flakes of Wrath but starts to the left of it.

content.description: Fun trad route up an obvious left leaning, left facing corner.  After leading you can TR the difficult direct variation to the left.  One of the best routes here, maybe 4 stars?
content.protection: Friends to #3.5 with maybe an extra #2 and #2.5, medium to large stoppers.

climbs.name: Flakes of Bongo
climbs.fa: c 1989: Kyle Copeland (Bolted on-sight and ground up)

content.description: It may be possible to top-rope the first half of this route from the station on top of Steel Your Face. But the swing becomes increasingly dangerous the higher you get.
content.protection: Most of the bolt hangers have been flattened on this. I don't recommend attempting to restore this route to its original state. An unknown person will likely destroy the hardware and continue destroying the rock more than they already have.
content.location: Between Chris Cross and Steel Your Face.

content.description: A TR opportunity once you send Fist Full of Potash.  The B-line from the ground up to the anchors on Fist Full Of Potash yields some so-so yet interesting face climbing.  For no more effort than this requires, it is worth taking a spin on after the original line, but otherwise doesn't merit going out of your way.
content.protection: Really not anything, so just TR it.
content.location: About 6' left of the initial bolts on Fist Full Of Potash the face can be climbed directly up to the crack and bulge on that route.

content.description: Hard opening moves lead to fun face climbing and a show stopper crux at the anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts
content.location: Right of "Baby Blue".

content.description:
Eyes of Falina

climbs the broken face left of

Bad Moki Roof

. Good holds get you off the deck to a precarious sequence of moves. Pull these off, gain a ledge, and clip the first bolt. Slab, edge, and lean left to gain a pin. Continue climbing up through a crack system to a nice rest/ledge. Slab up and right off the ledge towards some fair and most likely sandy edges. Follow the four inch crack for about fifteen feet to the anchors.
content.protection: Medium stoppers, gear to a #4 camalot, slings, and draws.
content.location:
This route starts directly left of

Bad Moki Roof

and right of

Flakes of Wrath

. You can identify the route by one high, red bolt about 20 feet off the ground.

content.description: It can be done as two pitches or one. I found it fine to string the pitches together. The first half is an easy slab then it moves into the dihedral with the crux being near the start of the corner. After this a few more tricky moves gain some cruising layback moves to the anchors.
content.protection: A set of nuts and some quickdraws for the bottom. Then cams .75-3 with a few extra #1's
content.location: This climb is the prominent corner (left or right depends on where you look from) above the Willams Bottom campground. Try to avoid making more trails to the base. Although it's annoying bring a second rope for the rappel. Unless you're comfortable rapping off one bolt.

content.description: Tradiak strikes again! Easy climbing leads to a pedestal, from which it is wise to place 2 #2 Camalots with a 48' runner. Balance-y climbing heads left onto the "faith flake". Karl's book mentions to girth hitch the flake, but this seems very unlikely unless you have a coat hanger. Mantle up onto the flake and clip the bolt. Technical climbing leads past two fixed pins and a single yellow Alien placement to the anchor. Great climbing on good stone. The meat of this one is interestingly similar to the nearby "Coup D'Etat."
content.protection: 2 #2 Camalots with a long runner, 3 draws, and a yellow Alien. Draws for the anchor.
content.location: Next route right of Cracko Diablo and Diablo Direct.

content.description:
Aesthetic and clean,

El Face-o-Diablo

will somehow leave you feeling a little dirty?

Deceptively difficult! What looks like a walk in the park, climbs more like a mugging.  A thin and slippery start greets the unsuspecting climber. Hard to hold on too, the beginning for most will unleash a brutal beating. Thin crimps, shallow side-pulls, awkward feet, and off-balance movement make this more of a battle than a climb. If you can make it to the first bolt, keep your guard up, its not over!

Most always run as a top-rope, this route can be led, rehearsal is advised as the first bolt is well above the crux moves and about 15-18 feet high.
content.protection: Three bolts and an a shared chain anchor. If top roping, use draws and the bolts which serve as invaluable directionals.
content.location:
Set a few feet right of

El Cracko Diablo

, this route is the clean and cut face with bolts connecting to the same anchor.

content.description: Haven't led this (so sad).  20' left of the tree on the black wall is a noticable V-slotted finger crack below a block.  Fingers to good jams then move around the block.  Rating is 10a and I think it's that all the way (look...a poet and I didn't even know it).
content.protection: Set of cams and a .5 TCU near the top.

content.description:
Eat the Rich is quite fun, but so short.  It's a little bit sustained but presents hand jams in the middle that ease climbing.  As a pretty short finger crack you will be wishing for more.  The crux is the last couple moves at the top where the crack thins and you must negotiate less straight-forward movement to clip the chains.

Find this climber's left of the 5.8 slab, or climber's right of Static Cling.  It's on the climber's right side of the HUGE pullout on the downstream end of Wall Street.
content.protection: Short route, small rack from .4 inch to 2".  You can get a red AND gold camalot in on this route.  Top can be protected by purple Metolius sized cam, or a nut.

content.description: Start up "Flakes Of Wrath" move right at first horizontal then up short splitter. Climb straight up to anchor, great face climbing with good gear!
content.protection: nuts- #3 camalot

content.description:
This route was not unpleasant, it just was not worth much. There weren't even any cool moves on it. I did it because I was there, I was waiting, and I was antsy, and I was at the top of this flake... (having just done Pedigree Poodles and having discovered no fixed anchors, or evidence that there ever were any). Like it's neighbors, this is a better boulder than it is a route. It is also harder than the book would imply, & not very secure to start.  A fall from the starting slopers would be very near the ground and not of much consequence unless you stumbled backward into traffic.

Again, just solo this up or down in combination with Manicured Lawns (5.9) or Pedigree Poodles(5.7).

All of these routes lie on the arch-shaped flake which lies against the main wall between Nervous In Suburbia and Lucy In the Sky with Potash. Dunn Copeland ascends the left-hand side of the flake to the top, perhaps for 30 feet, although is is not as tall, the climb is made longer by the 20' of horizontal you gain when traveling the hypotenuse of the triangular feature. The moves are not at all hard but the rock is pretty sandy and sloper. You can climb this as a ramp or a hand traverse. The hand traverse is harder, but more secure; you are closer to the ground that way if that is of concern to you. I had no gear here and only went back up to place some later to protect the swing for my second. It will take a TCU or two, but not much.

For an anchor up at the top of this flake, you can place cams back behind the flake up top, but the cables will get tweaked hard if someone takes a fall on them or hangs. I lead this route on a few pieces of gear in a solid arc up Pedigree Poodles and down over to the top of Dunn Copland and then down the sloping ramp of that route. I reached the ground, and handed the lead line to my second, who back lead it in reverse - pulling the gear out by reversing my direction. This turns the 2 routes into a mellow rising and falling traverse of the system covering ~50-60 feet of climbing.
content.protection: A few small cams to the top and 1.5-3" cams to protect the top if necessary. Maybe large tricams would be better to avoid tweaking cam stems.

content.description:
Described in the Falcon "Best climbs Moab" as "tricky" and a 5 bolt sport route going at 5.10.

It has 5 bolts, the first about 15 or more feet off the ground clipped from an insecure stance. It is tricky at the crux. I would take a few small cams for the pods en route to the first bolt of this sport climb. I whined, sniveled etc more than I think I ever have on a mid grade 5.10. For comparison, I found all the other 10s in this routes vicinity to be significantly easier. Your mileage may vary.

Still, fun, sequency moves on typical sand covered crimps to a creaky flake.
content.protection: 5 draws and a few small to mid size cams.
content.location: Imediately right of Fistful of Potash, first route left of the Schoolroom Slabs on a small buttress.

content.description: Fun featured slab climbing past a bolt leads into a left-facing corner. Follow the corner until it ends then finish on third class slab to the anchor.
content.protection: A bolt protects the crux at the bottom, then a set of cams from BD .5 - 4 should see you to the anchor.
content.location: Devil in Disguise starts up in the gully between Chocolate Chunk and Yogini. It's easier to get to the base of the route from the left side of the gully than from the right.

climbs.name: Desp-Arete
climbs.fa: Kyle Copeland and Linus Platt, 92 or 93

content.description: A thuggy little climb with a puny name. Start on the arete making some scary moves to get to the high first bolt. Easier climbing along the arete gains a slab and a long runout to the second bolt where the angle of the rock kicks back to vert. A few moderate moves ensue, using the arete and edges on the face. The climbing gets harder at the 4th bolt with a cool arete slapping sequence. Clip the last bolt and manage the poor feet to climb to the anchor.
content.protection: Five bolts
content.location: Located one route to climbers left of Man After Midnight. The start is usually pretty bushy. Look for a well bolted black arete.

content.description: Probably the best sport climb at Wall Street.  To the right of 30 Seconds, about 50 yards.  Easily recognizable by the dark varnished high quality rock.  The start is very chalked.  The crux is basically the first few moves off the ground.  After the third bolt it gets easier, but the bolts get a little further.
content.protection: QDs

content.description: Coup D'etat is a very good, technical, albeit short route with mostly good rock. Powerful moves off the deck, with more power/tech moves for the duration. Care should be taken getting to the drilled angle. I fell there on my first go and met my belayer just a foot off the ground. There was only one bolt with tat for an anchor, so with Linus' permission I added another and cleaned it up. Hopefully this will draw some attention to an unheralded classic. Linus had a great eye!
content.protection: I used a crash pad to get started, then placed a .5 and .75 in the obvious crack. After that there is one drilled angle and one bolt that will see you to the anchor. Just under the second bolt is a slot for either a purple or green c3 sized cam if desired.
content.location: Immediately left of El Cracko Diablo

content.description: A pretty good route with some insecure sections.  The status of the once-present protection is not so good, making a more direct ascent in the corner no more runout than the formerly bolted face.  The overall protection of this route, even if the rock were bullet-hard, would still be pretty sparse and scarey.  As such, it is presently a TR to the Steel Your Face anchors around the corner.  The crux may well be coming around that corner up top, on the soft rounded arete.
content.protection: A few pieces here and there that I did not place, nor study.  I would advise a TR from the 'Steel Your Face' anchors on a 60 meter rope.
content.location: This route climbs the huge left-facing dihedral, or that same dihedral and a few face moves left of it, just left of Steel Your Face.

content.description: Cool tips/bouldery crux up high, with a different crux down low for potash road.
content.protection:
00- #2 camalot

4 bolts
content.location: Climb  "Another Roadside Distraction 5.10b" first 20 feet and then bust left.

content.description: The easiest route on Wall Street. Popular with little kids.
content.protection: 3 bolts and a two bolt station with rappel hangers.
content.location: Between Neopolitan and Yogini.

content.description:
Wandering crack of varying sizes with a bolt near top. Two spinning bolt anchors at top of formation, recommended to bring some static line to extend anchor (to prevent further rope damage to rock).

Also, the face to the left of the climb can be top roped (face to the right should not be climbed as it contains petroglyphs)
content.protection: #0.75 to #4 Camelots, the crux is the second overhang with a #5 Camelot or hex, or just skip protection and clip the bolt just above it. There is only a two bolt anchor that is very far back from the top (both hangers spin and are out of the rock about 1/4"), or you can walk off the route.
content.location: Located in the middle of the Williams Bottom campground.

content.description: The route is of poor quality.  Climb the broken rock left of Neopolitan past bolts to an anchor with chains.  No trad gear needed.
content.protection: 1 fixed piton, 1.3" cam.
content.location: Between "Lip Balm Addict" and "Neopolitan".

content.description: Route is located 15 feet left of Banana Peel. Face climbing past 5 bolts to 3 bolt and chain anchor. Climb just right of the bolt line on better rock. You can make the route a bit harder by climbing left of the last 2 bolts.
content.protection: Five bolts with bolted anchor.
content.location: Bolted line left of Banana Peel.

climbs.name: Broken Engagements
climbs.fa: Luke Malatesta - Jason Lantz, Scott Deputy (Pitch 2&3)

content.description:
Aid route located above "top forty" and the far right side of the school room. climb to the top of the school room slabs and continue hard right past a bolt, ending at a bolted belay and the start of the first pitch

Pitch 1- bolt ladder to beaks and thin pins.Steep. Hanging belay (A3?)

Pitch 2- More thin pins and arrows to clean gear and a nice ledge. (A2+)

Pitch 3- 5.10ish ending in an alcove.

Could continue to the rim but I decided to back off as loose rock end up in the middle of the road, and there is a fair amount of it on the last pitch. Use caution.
content.protection: Lots of beaks and thin pins. Cams to #2 Camalot
content.location: Right side of schoolroom #2, above "top 40"

content.description: Hard to believe that this route hasn't been added yet. It's up there with Big Sky Mud Flaps as one of Wall Street's best face/slab climbs. Very cool and varied features. A hard mantle at the first bolt gains you entry into 30 meters of engaging face and slab climbing. Josh Gross tells me Lynn Sanson recently replaced the bolts on this, making an oft-neglected classic accessible again. Thanks Lynn!
content.protection: Bring 17 draws, 15 for the climb and 2 for the anchors. 70 meter rope is mandatory. Tie a knot in the end!
content.location: Just left of the Frogs/Shoot up routes. Last route before the gully

content.description:
A spectacular line up a thin left-facing corner to the right side of an arch. Stem and edge up the corner and its outside arête (crux between bolts 3 and 4) to an anchor right of the arch. 4 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.

It seems like this route doesn't have a lot of traffic on it but it's really fun climb. Desperate double knee-bars at the beginning with some old bolts and drilled pitons leads to the fun top part above some small pro.

A bit sandy ...
content.protection: 2 old bolts + 2 drilled pitons on the crux section + small Stoppers, 2 offset Aliens, small yellow TCU, BD # 0.4
content.location: To the right of the "30 Seconds over Potash"

climbs.name: Big Sky Mud Flaps
climbs.fa: Kyle Copeland, Charlie Fowler, Marc Hirt

content.description:
This is excellent desert face and friction, and is a fairly sustained route (and long for Potash).  It weaves its way up to a bulge and then around it to the right.  Continue slight left again and then upwards to an anchor some 100 feet up.  The length of the climb itself might be more like 110 ft due to weaving.

The crux comes high on the climb; it is friction moves a few feet off the last drilled angle.  Have fun, and BTW this route is evolving every year with each ascent.

Use a 70 m, or two ropes, to get down safely.
content.protection: A dozen quickdraws should cover it - I think.

content.description:
Short overhanging start followed by chimney protected by small gear. The rest of the route is a squeeze up a flake that is much more solid than it looks. Save a .5 for the top.

I found it to be pretty solid, at least compared to a lot of other desert routes. It's not Wall Street clean, but plenty clean enough to have a good time. This would be a great offwidth for those relatively new to the wide.
content.location: 8' left of Desp-Arete

content.description:
"Best Route Ever" is what the late great Dave Pegg would express after any new route he had completed once returning home! Fun mixed route! Early on in the pitch there are a couple of bolts that were placed. Falling onto trad gear there would explode the flake making the route unclimbable.

The route was put up ground up, in my personal opinion going ground up on mixed routes tends to make for a better flow to the route!  Half way up the pitch after a short hands section we busted right do to rock quality in the bulge. Higher up on the pitch a super fun slanting tips crack is encountered. We did not clean out right of this system FYI. This pitch is 30 meters on the nose , don't use a short 60meter rope!
content.protection:
00 BD C3

.3 BD x 2

.4 BD x 3

.5 BD x 1

.75 BD x 1

2 BD x 1

10 Quick Draws
content.location: "B R E "  begins on the top of "Points West". From the top of "Points West " head up and right towards a left facing corner.

content.description:
Nice face climb on the rightside of School Room #2. It is fairly sustained and has tricky moves at the start, above 1st pin and getting to the anchor.  Climb trends to the right and is well protected with 6 fixed pieces.

This climb was not in Eric B's "Wall Street to the SR Swell" guide book so if anyone has the real name, grade and 1st ascent info, please provide it.
content.protection: 6 bolts/driled pins to rap anchors
content.location: 12' right of "Grama and the Green Suede Shoes" and 25' left of Lacto Mangulation

content.description:
Climb a steep start to gain the groove. Cheater stones on the ground may help with getting started if you're shorter. Once gaining the groove move right into the large groove. Eventually you'll be able to move left onto a steep slab with a thin darkly varnished crack that cuts horizontally across the face. Climb across the slab until you can reach the first of two bolts. Climb the slab and finish at the anchor.

In High on Moab this is listed as Unnamed and it makes it sound like you can solo up to the bolts but most likely people will want to place some gear to gain the bolt protected slab.
content.protection: 2 bolts and tiny to finger sized cams and stoppers.
content.location: To the right of the big roof climbed by Horizontal Mambo is a water polished groove and drainage. Start in that groove in a weakness with a crack to the right of a steep panel of rock.

content.description: This route is two routes right of Flakes of Wrath.  It goes up the thin, slabby right facing corner, out the roof, and up a sandy slab/crack.  It felt harder than 5.9, since I got really pumped placing gear in the roof, but none of the moves are that hard, it's just sustained.  Don't lower and try not to toprope since there are really deep rope grooves in the roof.  One groove just above the lip is deep enough to place pro in.
content.protection: Small cams and maybe a few stoppers for beginning and end, #.75 to #2 camalots for roof section, fixed anchor at top.

content.description:
Climb a steep start to gain the groove. Cheater stones on the ground may help with getting started if you're shorter. Once gaining the groove work left on balance moves to gain the left facing corner system. Work up the corner and finish on the slab with two bolts and the anchor.

High on Moab describes and Unnamed 5.6 but the line described here is more straight forward, higher quality and easier to protect than the slab start described in the book.
content.protection: 2 bolts plus finger to hand size cams.
content.location: To the right of the big roof climbed by Horizontal Mambo is a water polished groove and drainage. Start in that groove in a weakness with a crack to the right of a steep panel of rock.

content.description:
This route is located approximately 100' left of '30 Seconds Over Potash' on Wall Street.  The route climbs a finger crack in a narrow, left facing dihedral.  Eight feet below the chains the dihedral vanishes, leaving a splitter finger crack.

This is a great route for the aspiring 5.11 crack climber.  There are numerous face holds and good stemming rests.  Excellent.
content.protection: A couple #1, #2 Metolius, .3, .4, .5 Camalots.

content.description: Astro Lad is the proud thin crack a few routes to the right of Bad Moki Roof.  It is obvious when you see 2 bolts halfway up and a bunch of chalk on the other side of the right facing dihedral.  Start with finger locks and liebacking to a good rest and clip 2 bolts to the jamming crux.  Sustanined climbing makes this one a battle to the end.
content.protection: Cams from greem alien to yellow camalot(2).  Medium stoppers help as well with the finger locks.

content.description:
This is the direct corner with a bolt.

shares the start and finish with Astro Lad
content.protection: 1 set .3-2 + QD
content.location: Astro Lad direct corner

content.description: Karl's book lists this as .12a/b but Linus told me he thought it was desperate at .12+. I would agree. Getting to the first bolt alone felt super hard, and getting past it felt impossible. Again, another route that I would love to hear about someone doing. Cold temps are likely crucial.
content.protection: Bolts and drilled angles
content.location: Second route left of Walk on the Wide Side

content.description: The crux is down low between the 2nd and 3rd bolts. You can go two different ways here: directly up on good but balancy feet or to the left of the bolt line on some thin holds. After the crux the route trends right, then up through a small break in the cliff to the anchor.
content.protection: Bolts to rappel anchor.
content.location: The bolted line 20 feet right of She-la the Peeler.

content.description:
A.R.D. is the right facing corner just left of Astro Lad.  This route begins with some funky moves and then veers left to avoid a short offwidth crack.  A large cam, anything from a #4 friend to a #5 camalot, protects the start.  The rock on the first half of the route is definitely a little suspect, but the moves are interesting.  At mid-height, cut back right to gain the beautiful finger crack.  I'd recommend placing a good piece (#2.5 Fr.?) with a long sling before going right.  Load up the thin crack with pro and launch into a fun layback with solid finger locks.  A  couple small footholds provide relief for placing gear during the layback.

The crux is giving up the layback and hoisting onto the sloping ledge just before the anchor.  The last half of the route is excellent!
content.protection: 2 sets cams, something big for the start, #2 yellow TCU's fit the crux lieback perfectly, so three of those come in handy.  A couple long slings are helpful, depending on where your gear ends up.

content.description: Dust off your shoes before smearing to the first bolt.  The line travels slightly left of the bolt then follows edges to the anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts plus 2 bolt anchor
content.location: 10' left of Brown Banana.

content.description: This route is just left of a slabby top-roping area on a small buttress that almost goes into the road.  Climb up the slab past bolt and pitons to a short finger crack to a ledge with anchors.  The slab is probably is harder for shorter people.
content.protection: A bolt and two fixed pitons at the start, a few finger sized cams for the upper crack.

content.description: Starting off on some mossy rock with an under cling pocket make your way up L of the first bolt. Once established on the climb enjoy a fun dance L and R of the bolted line following the path of least resistance. A good variety of smears and ripples lead to a section of deceiving friction just before the anchors.
content.protection: 8 bolts to chains
content.location: This is the bolted line in the trees just L of “Seamed like a good idea”.

content.description:
This is one of the classic must-do moderate routes.  It almost always has someone on it or in line (sorta like Supercrack at IC).  And it's definitely worth the wait.  Expect a sustained climb with three definite parts, and good rests in between each - it's harder than it looks, and the cruxes are pumpy.

Reach the climb about 350 feet (less than .1 mile) past a large break in the otherwise solid wall of Wall Street.  If you pass a long (several hundred feet) section of lower angled slabs, you've gone too far.

Lieback and jam a left-facing corner (with a couple of face features for variety) at the right end of a 3-car turnout for 80' to good anchors on the facing wall.  Rap the route.
content.protection: Standard rack to #3 camalot, small to medium TCUs and chocks, and a pink tri-cam is useful off the ground.

content.description: This route climbs a large, continuous right facing corner.  There is a bolt about 20 feet up and another about 60 feet up.  You may find a few tricky placements before the first bolt.  This is a fun route that requires stemming, jamming, finger locks and a variety of techniques.  It is fairly sustained with a few distinct cruxes.  The rock quality is better than it looks and should clean up with more traffic but is still quite sandy in spots.
content.protection: Standard desert rack.
content.location: 150 right of the School Room #1, 70 feet right of Smoke Filled Rooms
